title: 107_s1686
content: The Act may be cited as the "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001". The Congress recognizes the importance of adequate and safe healthcare delivery, supported by research showing better patient outcomes with higher nurse staffing levels. Despite difficulties in recruiting and retaining nursing staff, healthcare providers still rely on mandatory overtime, contributing to nurse dissatisfaction and departures from the profession. The widespread use of mandatory overtime in healthcare contributes to nurse dissatisfaction and departures from the profession. Limiting mandatory overtime will ensure patient safety, quality healthcare services, and aid in nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Provider agreements under the Social Security Act are amended to include compliance with limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. This prohibits providers of services from enforcing mandatory overtime, except under specific circumstances. The Social Security Act now includes limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses, prohibiting providers from requiring nurses to work beyond scheduled shifts or specific hour limits. Exceptions apply during declared states of emergency. The Social Security Act limits mandatory overtime for nurses to 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions during declared states of emergency. Nurses can only work beyond these limits if the provider has tried to fill staffing needs through alternative means. The Social Security Act limits mandatory overtime for nurses to 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions during declared states of emergency. Nurses can work beyond these limits if the provider has made efforts to fill staffing needs through alternative means, and the work requirement does not extend past the end of the state of emergency or the provider's direct role in responding to medical needs. Nurses have the right to report violations. Nurses can work beyond these limits if the provider has made efforts to fill staffing needs through alternative means, and the work requirement does not extend past the end of the state of emergency or the provider's direct role in responding to medical needs. Nurses have the right to report violations to the Secretary against providers who violate these provisions. The Secretary has a procedure for nurses to file complaints, investigates violations, and can require providers to establish a plan of action or face civil penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination, retaliation, or penalties by providers. The Secretary has a procedure for nurses to file complaints and investigate violations. Providers must not penalize or discriminate against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime or report violations. Employees who refuse to work mandatory overtime or report violations are protected from penalties or discrimination. They can report violations to regulatory agencies, accreditation bodies, or management, participate in investigations, or discuss with other employees. Providers cannot retaliate by filing complaints against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime. Employees are protected from penalties or discrimination for refusing mandatory overtime or reporting violations. Providers cannot retaliate against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime by filing complaints. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith if they believe the information reported is true and a violation has occurred or may occur. Each provider of services must post notice conspicuously. Each provider of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights, including the ability to file complaints with the Secretary for violations. A nurse may file a complaint with the Secretary against a provider of services for violating regulations. Providers must post nurse schedules and make them available upon request. The Secretary can impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of regulations by a provider of services, with more severe penalties for repeated violations. The Secretary may impose more severe civil money penalties for providers of services that establish patterns of repeated violations. The administration of penalties follows the provisions of section 1128A. Information on providers against whom penalties have been imposed will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Secretary will publish names of providers facing civil money penalties, along with violation details. Penalties for providers under previous ownership won't be published after 1 year. No restrictions on nurses working longer hours voluntarily. The Secretary will not publish penalties for providers under previous ownership after 1 year. Nurses can work longer hours voluntarily as long as it meets professional standards of safe patient care. Mandatory overtime is defined as hours worked in excess of specified periods. "Overtime is defined as hours worked in excess of specified periods, requested by a service provider to a nurse, with potential adverse consequences if refused. A nurse can be a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse." The term 'overtime' refers to working beyond specified periods. A 'nurse' can be a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse. A 'provider of services' includes various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, clinics, and home health agencies. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency. It excludes emergencies resulting from labor issues. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency, excluding emergencies resulting from labor disputes. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to recognized professional standards governing the profession of the nurse involved. The amendments made by this section will take effect 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing healthcare, considering various factors. A report must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Director will conduct a study to determine overtime practices in federally operated medical facilities. A report with recommendations for maximum work hours standards must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study overtime practices in federally operated medical facilities, including hospitals, clinics, and home health care clinics. The study aims to identify inconsistencies with the Social Security Act and must be completed within 2 years. The term "federally operated medical facilities" includes hospitals, clinics, and home health care clinics run by government departments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress within 6 months on a study regarding overtime policies for nurses in these facilities, aligning with section 1866(j) of the Social Security Act.
